reviewText:
Early Access Review

1st and 4th  Squad are moving into to take a bridge in the middle of the town.  Myself and the rest of 2nd Squad are perched up on top of Hill 15.  A hill which we had just taken away from militia control only moments before.  Our Sgt. has us build defenses and before you know it we have a small but capable FOB from which we provided covering fire and relayed enemy movements to our squads in town.  Our Sgt. got a radio call from 4th squad saying they were pinned down by enemies coming in through the southern entrace of the town.  He made the call to move 2nd squad down into the town west and through the middle to come out on the other side and catch the militia out in the open.  Well the militia saw it coming and in between rounds of AK and RPK fire we were ordered to fall back to the center of town to regroup and resupply.  I look around for my squad and I only see the autorifleman, Dunlap.  Dunlap and I were split from our squad by a sea of angry militiamen.  So we cautiously make our way back through the town.  Covering each other as we cross alleys, streets, fields.  I didn't even know his first name and yet he was my best friend.  Finally catching up to the squad I suddenly hear a loud snap and my vision faded out.  I'd been shot.  Dunlap was calling out to me telling me to hold on but before I knew it he was down too.  We laid there, taking in our last breaths thinking about how we got there.  But it wasn't over yet.  A friendly voice approached.  A fellow rifleman, phozz, had come to our rescue.  After a few moments of silence he said something so profound, so life changing, it shook me to the core...F*** I don't have a medkit"

-----

For real though
date: this game is awesome and I can't wait to see where it goes.  There is a learning curve but it's nowhere near as steep as say Arma's or OFP.  You can jump right in and the community (so far...don't let me down here guys) has been very helpful and an absolute joy to play with.  The in game VOIP is the best I've ever used in any game period.  It's great to see a competitive shooter that absolutely hinges on team play.  And the sound design my GOD!!! The distance sounds of gunshots and explosions made me anxious to move up and see what exactly was going on.  The weapon sounds are spot on in this game.  My heart was pounding as a sniper was taking shots at us as we took cover in our FOB.  I'm a milsim fanatic so I can't recommend this game enough to people who enjoy milsims and tactical shooters alike.  Play it. Love it.  Play it some more."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Decision to buy this was very hard for me.
The Price is kinda insane for Early Access and if i look into my Library i see DayZ
and suddenly i have a bad feeling about Early Access.
First, if you are not sure if it runs well or just doubt in general, buy it and try it out.
(under 2 hour playtime, you can refund it).

So my first Game was basically sitting on a Mountaintop and trying to shoot or see the enemy on another Mountaintop, ye well the most exciting thing was to build a Base together with the team and try to change the Situation to one where not everyone of us dies straight away. It is sooo hard to see enemies over a distance.

For me this Game seems to be most fun if you defend and build a base, of course.

Exactly that happened in my second Game.
I joined a German server and played in a german squad, everybody was working together and it was fun. We secured a Compound and prepared to defend, there they came...
Dont try to shoot an RPG through a Doorway, might get TKs for that xD
... while trying to apologize to the remains of my Teammates, i was trying to bring down some nice RPG fire on those enemies closing in from two Directions. We cant go on the rooftops. We cant peek. We try to fortify us with more Sandbags. I hide behind a Wall in the middle of our Compound, a Medic runs up to me to get some healing done. I look at him, a young boy maybe 18, he shows no fear, he does his best as a Medic.
Suddenly a read cloud, noooooo Jimmy !!!!! he gets shot ! an enemy made it through one of the side entrances.
I hide behind the same Wall, reload my RPG and peek out.
Click! There it flys right into his Face, i see his body flying to the left.
I look at Jimmy. The squadleader shouts to hold the position. I get my AK out and run to the uncovered spot where the enemy broke through. R.I.P Jimmy

Overall i can recommend this Game after my first Session today. The long Range visibility Problem is annoying, but you just cant change that on such big Maps, not seeing enemies is also kinda realistic. This aint no COD baby.


EDIT 1: No Matter how i change the Graphic Settings i always seem to get above 40 frames and in some situations it drops to 30. I hope that performancewise a notable change will happen soon. Still not bored of this game :)

EDIT 2: Srsly some of these people cant be legit... i cant see a ♥♥♥♥ing thing and i am not even visible and i already get shot at... there is no way they could know where i am crawling (up some random ♥♥♥♥ing hill in nowhere), i really like this game but it keeps frustrating me that 70% of the time you have no idea who shoots you and how they can see you. I understand that it is kinda the way it is supposed to be (realistic) but the visibility is so ♥♥♥♥ing bad, it feels like everybody else has WH and Aimbot sometimes. WE NEED A ZOOM FEATURE, without having to aim the weapon.
(please note, i wrote this when i was frustrated :P )

EDIT 3: If you want to watch a typical round on one of the shorter Gamemodes go ahead (yes i played this) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gw2e3Ekv45E

EDIT 4: I thought i just add a more action packed clip aswell, so you can see what the combat feels like when you defend a compund.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZdIoyZQZCEA

EDIT 5: So the new Version was released, good to see new content coming. They are also still trying new things out and they dont hesitate to remove them again (Aimblur), i like that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The timer starts, over 100 seconds before the match begins.
Squads are starting to form, led by those who choose the difficult task of leading 8 men into battle.

As the players pick their weapon systems, comms come alive with chatter from those within the squad and other squad leaders.

This is Squad Two, what's the plan lead?

Two, you've got a full squad, head to District and set down a F.O.B. in the cheesegrater compound SE of District. One will send a fire team to District to support and keep one team for F.O.B. placements around Aman Ridge/West Estate and Delta.

Copy One, heading to District.

One, this is Three, where do you want us?

Three, until your squad fills up, capture Abzel and Hill 15. Drop a F.O.B. at the marked location in grid India-7, NumPad 1. Once capped and the F.O.B. is dropped, head into District to support Two. I'll relay when to move up to West Estate once One decaps Delta Bridge.

Three copies.

Good luck fellas, maintain comms, mark targets on the map. We'll have a good game.

40 seconds remaining

***************

SQUAD LEAD! You gotta mic?!

Yes, fellas, thanks for waiting. Other squads are capping the first two objectives and moving to District, I need a fire team consisting of one medic, one optic and one support class with me. The rest, head to District to support Two and Three in capping and holding district.

Roger that Lead, let's do this!
Finally, a squad lead who talks.. fckn a.

Let's make sure to keep in contact, within reach of the medics and call out grids so I can mark targets. I need a Fire Team Leader for Team 2 at District, relay comms to him via local chat.

Got it, I'll take it.

Good to go. Weapon silent for my fire team unless engaged, move quick, head on a swivel.

Copy, Lead.
Roger Dodger
Allah hu Akhbar!!!!!

3 seconds remaining...
*******************************

Squad is in the process of evolving into the pinnacle of milsim FPS'. Even as an alpha, the gameplay and strategic processes involved in a coordinated battle between 72 individuals is as rigorous as any military themed CQC games. As new elements are introduced, such as the recent addition of new maps/and the famed Mod Deuce .50, the tactics previously used in past versions evolve to accomodate these new assets, so every month seems to bring about a new wave of ideas and strategies. New players are met with a new-player friendly game where roles are taken seriously and each individuals main purpose is to support the squad/fire team element to the maximum of their capacity. Whilst other modes highlighting talents of clan vs clan and precision on the battlefield, public games with random individuals who coordinate with each other effectively to win the game leads to a higher satisfaction of teamwork, leading to friends who will challenge you to become better and more effective on comms/gameplay/situational awareness. The graphics are amazing, and albeit the gore of wounds could leave a bit to be desired, the sounds of AK fire snapping overhead is enough for anyone to hit the dirt midsprint. I'd encourage any milsim/FPS aficionado to try Squad, spend a few hours playing each role and getting used to the dynamic of the game before stepping up the plate as a Squad Leader. For more information, find the JoinSquad" subreddit for up to date news
hoursPlayed: and dev responses for a feel of the amazing community behind Squad.\n\nSee you on the flipside

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following Squad since I saw it was announced on the Project Reality forum[www.realitymod.com] back in October 2014. I kept my eye out for any news of the game and then the Kickstarter campaign was announced in May 2015. I was a first day backer and I have not regretted my decision to back this game.

I've been playing Squad since the closed pre-alpha back in July 2015. Ok, enough dates. How does it play? In one word, amazing! If you are familiar with the large-scale teamwork oriented gameplay from Project Reality, then you will understand the type of gameplay the Squad developers are trying to achieve. There is nothing like being a part of a 9-man squad on a 50 player team going up against the enemy in epic 100p multiplayer battles on maps as large as 4km^2. There is nothing like it in PC gaming. ArmA? Kind of except you do not need to be part of a clan community to get the kind of teamwork that you need to be successful in this game. Insurgency? Not quite. The scale of Squad's maps are much larger than anything Insurgency has to offer. If you've been looking for a military tactical shooter on PC, I would highly recommend Squad.

This is the type of gameplay you can and will experience in Squad.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vtjsiCdNT3o

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Squad is an in interesting take on the Military Sim. It heavily focuses on squad based (obviously) infantry engagements, with the main goal to capture and hold more positions than the enemy. The HUD is very simple adding to the sense of realism. This game feels like a more realistic Battlefield, but not as complicated as Arma 3. Considering it's only in alpha, i hope the devs keep their promises about expansion and the addition of vehicles and anticheat. So far it's an incredibly immersive experience that leaves you forgetting you're even playing a video game. It's very unique. Squad requires you have a great deal of patience, and are able to take orders from competent squad leaders. Without a good squad leader you can often end up in a state of chaos where the enemy can easily overrun you. So you need to be good at learning and adapting quickly to intense situations to get any enjoyment out of the game. A good mic helps too.

PROS:
+ Incredibly Realistic Sounds & Gameplay
+ Requires heavy teamwork and voice communication
+ Gun ballistics feel very close to real life
+ Has a large playerbase

CONS:
- Takes time and patience to learn
- Having a microphone is essential
- Price is rediculous for an alpha
- Some servers take the game way too seriously
- US servers are incredibly toxic compared to EU/AU

BOTTOM LINE:
If you enjoy military simulations and you're okay with cutting the fat and getting straight into infantry combat, Squad may be for you. As long as you have the patience to listen, learn, and adapt, you'll have a fun time.

Recommended.
8/10 If i didnt already have PTSD i'd have it now.

Being squad leader, and your squad calling you a good leader, really is a great feeling, it can get pretty stressfull in the beginning, I've been there, other squads being mad at us because of different reasons which we cant do anything about.

I've played Project Reality, and I can't wait until this game is going to be just like it, my biggest hype for now is urban combat, next to that are the helicopters. I remember in Project Reality I was in a city by a port (forgot the name of the map) and being on the rooftops and seeing the whole city and a seeing a missile come in somewhere in the city and just that huge explosion while Black Hawk's are flying in and out and Bradley's rolling in the streets with Humvee's behind it, cannot wait until seeing that happen again, but this time in Squad.

This game is all about communication, I know you have seen it in allot of other games, like Battlefield or CoD, but there is never communication in it, it's just allout rush in, I can tell you, this game is nothing like those games, 'CoD is full with strategy' 'Only in Battlefield'  my @ss, this is where its all about tactics and strategy, keep with your squad, and if you're like that CoD kid, new to these games, and thinking like 'I'm rushing the left side on my own' I swear, you will get brutally killed by enemy squads while the people in your squads are calling you names because you dind't listen.

Forget everything you know about CoD strategy (which is only rushing) and go look some ganeplay video's of squad, I'd say watch BlueDrake42 just to get an idea how this game is supposed to be, and not like what you probably had in mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I dont write reviews often, but this game does deserve one.

Even tho it's still alpha, the game is great. You won't find the feeling you get when you play it anywhere else. The adrenaline rush when you're assaulting an entrenched enemy position or when you're the last man standing in your squad and still manage to kill the remaining soldiers of the enemy squad that just wiped out yours is something hard to describe, those games when your squad is the only one defending a keypoint, outnumbered, while everyone else is out there to capture the next flag... And it will only get better when they add vehicles and bigger maps, note that the ingame maps are already huge when compared to other shooters.

I hear some people are experiencing problems with AMD processors, which isn't my case. Also, you need to have windows updated since the game requires Microsoft Visual C++ 2015 to work. The game runs smoothly on my 4 years old rig, so I'ld say its well optmized despite being alpha.

TL;DR: if you're looking for a war game, you found it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is time. Time for me to sit down and review this game having put in a solid 20+ hours and now have a grasp on what this game is about and what that might mean for you the player/consumer. Take a minute to read through my review and if there are too many words and letters, skip to the end for my final verdict. I use a standard review format on Steam when it comes to categories, so some apply, some do not. This is probably one of the most honest reviews you'll find on here so take that or leave it.


Overview
What is Squad? When I first heard about this game I admittedly missed the Kickstarter, missed the big news announcements, missed the gaming convention announcements, I basically goofed and came into this late. I saw the name and the logo on Steam (as an upcoming title) and was immediately unimpressed. Squad"? That's lame.  Then I watched the trailer. My interest was piqued.

So I did some digging and research. Found out the game is the spiritual successor to the mod
date: "Project Reality" made by those mod devs. I had played PR when it first came out many many years ago and haven't touched it since. So I had NO idea what they did to it.\n\nI then watched pre-Alpha gameplay and immediately realized this was a game I was looking for. As a former military servicemember (Marine Corps Infantryman)
recommended: and a tactical realism player this game seemed to fit right into my gaming niche. I found the Kickstarter page which showed vehicles they intended to put in
hoursPlayed: and other great and amazing features you don't find much in today's shooters.\n\nFast forward to Steam launch and now I get to experience it. This is a hardcore
voteText: unrelenting tactical shooter. It's an in your face
helpfulPercent: no holds barred look into life on the battlefield. As someone who set foot in Iraq conducting combat operations
votesHelpful: this game felt like what real life does (as best as any game can).\n\nYou'll find yourself hunkered down behind H-Barriers with snaps of rounds over your head
votesTotal: grenades blowing up nearby
votesFunny: and a constant state of utter confusion as to WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON?! Your radio will be blowing up in your ear as squadmates call out contacts
commentsCount: and you'll be engaged in some brutal firefights. But
column16:
not all the time (see below).


Graphics
Graphics are extremely important to a lot of people in this day in age. Many PC gamers will spend thousands of dollars on ridiculous rigs and expect top notch graphics as a result. So it's worth noting the graphics in this game in my review.

Squad utilizes Unreal Engine 4... which is arguably one of the best engines available to the masses right now on a commercial level. I have a project of my own I am working on with UE4 so while I could be called biased
column17: I did a lot of research. UE4 is strong
column18: powerful
column19: and stable. It's a well built engine that commercially speaking is cheap for the developer
column20: and allows some of the best graphical enhancements available today.\n\nSquad does a really solid job of having graphics that are on par with today's standards
column21: but cuts corners on some things. For example
column22: the player models don't exhibit facial expressions
column23: different facial models to look different than the exact same modeled player. When the player dies they look exactly like the model when they were alive (eyes open
column24: ready to go to work).\n\nThe ground textures can be underwhelming at times in some areas
column25: while the overall scope of everything you see on the screen can be absolutely stunning in some maps. It's a toss up but one thing is made clear
column26: the graphics are where they need to be and will only (likely) get better as the game is improved upon
column28:
and optimized.


Combat
This is why you bought this game or are contemplating it. The combat. This game features a realistic approach to a LARGE SCALE combat zone. Right now only infantry based
column29: you will fight on maps with upwards to 50 vs 50 players through wooded terrain
column32: and more.\n\nCombat in this game is unforgiving. If you slip up
column33: you die. If you run off on your own
column34: you'll probably die. If you move too fast
column35: you'll die. If you move too slow
column36: you'll die. You have absolutely GOT TO work with your teammates in order to succeed. I've seen guys go 70+ kills and less than 10 deaths. I've seen guys go with 10 kills and 70 deaths. Neither player was "better" than the other if they didn't contribute to the MISSION. If they ran off and did their own thing
column37: they were a terrible player regardless of stats.\n\nAs I said in my intro
column38: you will find yourself in rabid
column39: bite the neck battles. You may even come down to a hand to hand fight swinging E-tools with your enemy (that happened to me once). But other times you may feel like you're running for 10 minutes only to suddenly die by an invisible enemy (one you never saw coming) and have to respawn again. It's the hard nature of the game and oddly enough just like real life in the sense that you may do a lot of walking and may only see action for a few minutes.\n\nExpect to both love and hate the combat in this game. Expect some amazing experiences that once you put the headset down
column40:
you collect yourself and feel good about it... while also getting completely frustrated when your squad didn't work together.


Skills
column41: and Upgrades\nThe squad is the backbone of this game. "Upgrades" come in the form of classes for your player. Each one has a player model
column42: and each one has a kit (of gear). Each one unlocks with the more players you have in your squad.\n\nSo
column43: starting out with a squad of one... you'll have a Squad Leader. Add two players and you'll gain a medic slot
column44: and a fighter slot (standard infantry rifleman). Add more players and you gain access to RPG kits
column46:
and eventually the Marksman (sniper role). Each class is extremely important to the overall success or failure of the team.


Game Performance
I run a PC with the following specs:

AMD FX-8370 (8 core CPU) @ 4.01ghz
G.Skill RAM 16GB @ 1600mhz
Asus GTX 960 2GB
Windows 10

You have to understand one thing right off the bat... this is an Early Access (Alpha) title. If you can understand that and appreciate that
column47: you wont be disappointed. If you expect a bug free game
column51:
etc... you should not pick this game up.

I run an average of about 30fps. Sometimes less (around 20) sometimes more. I have most settings maxed with shadows on Medium. I normally put them on low but this game they appear like disgusting blobs (a fence will look like poka dots on the ground). So medium is my best performance to quality spot for shadows.

I have a few problems with being disconnected from servers (always at the worst time or when I feel like I'm rocking on the server). This is a known issue. But the overall performance of the game is pretty solid for an Alpha (better than most I've played).


SEE MY FINAL VERDICT IN THE COMMENTS SECTION OF THIS REVIEW

I had to cut this review short because of Steam's maximum character limit. See the remainder of my review in the comments section to the right (or below
column52: depending on where you are reading this)."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**ALPHA STATE REVIEW**

Review update:  After putting some time in I want to add to the review. An avid Battlefield or COD player will find this game boring. Most engagements occur with you trading fire at medium to long range, trying to shoot a target you can barely see. This game is very tactical and can be thrilling with radio chatter, real tactics and intense engagements when your squad leader is experienced.

Most attempts at a run and gun that works so well in other shooters just gets you killed fast in this game. Personally, I love that.

The maps are so huge you could spend the whole time circling the perimeters in flanking and not see the enemy, bad for the twitch shooter but good for the tactical military shooter. I've been laying in wait and when not moving you are very hard to see depending on the board and your cover. I was able to ambush several enemy soldiers before being overrun by players smart enough to stick together.

Had I been with my squad, we could have set up a perimter and held that position, setting up an F.O.B. so we can spawn there now then pushing forward towards the objective, which is always to take the enemies base at this time. F.O.B.s can be captured from the enemy as well and then used as spawn points.

Play is 9 man squads, up to 50 players per team though right now the norm is 36. The 100 player servers tend to crash when full at this time. You can join a squad or form your own. Players can select from roles such as Medic, Rifleman, Grenadier, Leader, Sniper etc with diffrent loadouts. Most weapons come with iron sights at this time making seeing the enemy first key.

Full microphone support, vehicles are slated to be added to the game as updates are distributed. No in game tutorial exists at htis tme, check below and YT for existing help videos.

Will update review as game evolves.


Original review:


Picure a modern military boots on the ground movie where you have a squad of soldiers all defending a perimeter, trading bullets at medium to long range while hunkered down behind cover. Six soldiers rush their positions, gunfire erupts as the charge is pushed back.

The radio crackles, Squad Leader calls for a push forward. Slowly they advance, covering eachother in leapfrogs, utilising smoke grenades, setting up F.O.B.s to establish a new front line.  You not only can you do this, the game is geared so you must do this.

Ths game plays out like a modern engagement, and it's in Alpha. Buggy but playable and totally awesome.

Wait for the sale but this game is what I have wanted in a FPS for a long time. Make sure you have a microphone and watch this video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mJ8lccr0u6M

It's Squad Tutorial so you can at least function with the basics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If Insurgency, Battlefield and Arma had a Child



The better way to describe Squad is a casual military first person shooter with realism elements. Perhaps it's not a diehard simulation like Arma 3, but like Arma 3, the challenge you'll get from Squad, despite it being about as casual as the Battlefield series of games, will keep you coming back for more.

Rich, authentic and downright chilling sound design and detailed environments which explore a range of variety in both scale, terrain type and infrastructure which can and will impact maneuverability of vehicles and foot soldiers.

Projectile arching is very much a thing to realize and compensate for with either firearms, rockets and of course grenades with grenades having an optional underhanded throw for shorter distances for those over-the-fence or out-the-window tosses.

Overpressure from explosions withing confind spaces like building interiors and backblast from rocket launchers exist as well. So even if you're fairly far away from a grenade when it goes off in the same building you're in, you'll still feel it or possibly even die from it. And think twice before firing an RPG inside of a building. Your eyeballs and lungs will explode and you'll also probably end up harming or killing other friendlies inside your building.

Moving is pretty good. The weapon sway/bob is a bit like Battlefield which gets annoying if you fail to work with it. But movement is pretty solid. This makes firing while absolutely stationary being the ideal position to fire from.

And keep in mind for this next body of text, there're differences between walking, jogging and sprinting. Jogging being the default speed which isn't stamina intensive.

Like sprinting, jumping requires stamina too and consumes stamina based on how many times you jump over a short period of time. This also limits how much you can jump as you need stamina for both sprinting and jumping. Although there is a key for switching between jogging and walking, there's almost no difference from what I can tell. I think walking increases the amount of stamina regenerated while still moving, but by an extremely small amount. Jogging from left to right is much slower than jogging back and forth but I guess it helps with clearing around corners with your sights up.

Moving up and down ladders in Squad is the most intuitive ladder mechanic I've ever seen in any game. Just walk into a ladder to go up and walk backwards to go down. Or vice-versa if you're turned around.

Moving around while prone is pretty cool. You always have  your weapon pointed outward and ready to fire like you would actually be able to do by crawling on your opposite forearm as your forward method of movement.

The communication is terrifically crisp and audible with a realistic radio audio filter slapped on for authenticity and immersion. Individual squad leaders can communicate with each other while the lower ranking soldiers are only able to communicate with their designated squad leader and vice-versa.

If you want the scale, infantry combat, communication and minor simulated elements of Arma, the sound quality, ease of movement and weapon aspects such as backblast of Insurgency and the casual accessibility and gameplay of Battleifeld then this is your game.

And it doesn't look half bad to boot! Unreal Engine 4 is quite pretty.



When I can, I'll be sure to update this review as this ALPHA game developes further down the road and features are both added and improved upon. Remember - everything about this game as I type this is subject to change.

Vehicles based on factions will be added as developement continues.

I believe TrackIR support will come eventually as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most of the reasons I love this game are well stated by every other review. Here's some buy/no buy advice based on what this game is and will be.

Reasons to Buy:
1. Teamwork. The thrill of accomplishing a common goal with a cohesive unit is greater than any other game I have ever experienced. (That's a lot of games)
2. Fellowship. It's fun to socialize with people like you and make life-long gaming friends. I certainly have.
3. Realism/Gameplay. Most people field these two as opposing forces that mark the difference between Arma and Battlefield; fun or boring; simulator or shooter. Gameplay > Realism? Realism > Gameplay? Squad has both. Realism = Gameplay. 'Nuf said.
4. Longevity. Squad's predecessor, Project Reality, has achieved a following since 2006 and has become a constantly enhancing game with updates still being pushed out. Squad is breathed by the same Gods and will be much the same.
5. Creators. The Devs will personally discuss with anyone on what they can do to improve the game just as they will watch your back during the heat of combat. This ain't EA. These guys care. They're giving it to you for $40 and someday it will be worth so much more. They deserve your money.
6. Renaissance. The concept that is this game is unique. Imagine Battlefield's combined warfare, Arma's teamwork, Red Orchestra's casualness, and Insurgency's flow. Add huge maps and much else and you get Squad. Why has no one made this game yet??

Reasons not to buy:
1. Early Access. Squad is not comparable or up to par with Project Reality. If you want a working game, patience you must have.
2. Immaturity/mic. Squad is designed for a mature player who can communicate by mic. You will not feel what this game has to offer if you possess neither of those.
3. Combat Pace. No 360' no scopin' fools. If you're partial to those games, you'll be disappointed here. Combat pace anywhere between Red Orchestra and Arma, depending on the map.
4. Walking Simulator. This will change when vehicles are added, but Squad will probably feel like a walking simulator to everyone at some point. Admirable graphics are an instant fix of this for me. IMO, most games don't give you the time to appreciate the finer textures and lights like this one will. Environment will immerse you.
5. Hardware. Currently in this un-optimized pre-alpha state, the performance is quite low when on populated servers. I probably would not be having fun if it weren't for GTX 780 + 4770k. Others may be frustrated if they purchase it so soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros: Great community with great servers that do a good job policing themselves. Huge, beautiful maps with great game modes. Some very intense firefights where maneuvering and coordination beats run & gun every time.

Cons: One of the most glitchy games ever, every map has a few players taking advantage of shooting through walls or terain with immunity. Scopes are OP, everyone rushes to fill those slots and the 10% of players with optics get 90% of the kills. If you don't have a scope, keep some Ibuprofen on hand because you'll spend the whole game a few inches from the screen trying to tell if those few pixels are a bush or an enemy, and hopefully not an enemy with a scope. Russians and US look too similar, so again, hopefully you have optics. You really need a decent computer so you can crank up textures so you can see what is what, hopefully you have optics. US are OP, their basic infantry have red-dots, it just isn't balanced.

Maybe in another year or two this game will be worth it, it is still in Alpha.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing SQUAD since March this year and have seen the great progress made by the Developers. At this point, Steam Early Access release, the game isn’t finished in its full vision - instead we are given a fantastic early access release. It is incredible that at this stage the game feels and plays so good and the amount of content already available in the game.

This is how a early access release should work. A great experience, demonstrating the core idea(s) and a roadmap to continue development.

I have played Project Reality, that mod for Battlefield 2 where most of these Developers cut their teeth. I played that mod from 2007 up until this year and I am excited to see what the Squad Dev team can do with this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As other reviewers have previously mentioned if you have an AMD based rig avoid this game entirely. It is completely unplayable, and I am not exaggerating in the least when I say this. Here are my computer's specifications:

1. AMD 8350 CPU
2. Noctua DH C-14 HSF
3. ASUS Radeon R9 280X
4. Asus Crosshair V Formula-Z Motherboard Revision 1.01 BIOS 1602
5. G.SKILL Ripjaws X 8GB (2 x 4GB) 240-Pin DDR3 SDRAM DDR3 1600 (PC3 12800) Memory Model F3-12800CL9D-8GBXL
6. CM-STORM TROOPER Computer Case
7.CORSAIR HX-1000W PSU
8. CRUCIAL M500 240GB SSHD.

With this in mind you would think based on the minimum system requirements set by SQUAD's developers I'd at least be able to play the game on its lowest possible graphics settings. Guess again, this game with graphics settings all turned on low and all optimization advice followed from SQUAD's sub-reddit,  doesn't even run above 25-FPS ever!

And if it does it stutters like crazy. I also know it has nothing to do with latency because all servers I played on had less than 60 ping.  To be honest I have no clue how this game is available for purchase on Steam as its essentially a crime considering the price.

I am not new to playing pre-alphas or alphas and I am not a new PC gamer.  This is the only game I have ever requested a refund for and I have purchased hundreds of games from Steam.  Please do yourself a favor and DO NOT purchase this game until the developers get serious about optimizing the game, because as it stands right now its the software equivalent of a $40 paper weight.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

it will be a Good Game as long as they finish of missing features and improve optimisation on Release.
Think of Project Reality with additiıonal positive features on Unreal Engine 4. ( Sounds good,right?)
-Alpha version 4.0 Review- Not Actual Finished Product!

Pros of Alpha:
+ Good Tactical Squad Play
+Good sounds
+Good İmmersion level of effects
+Decent Graphics "subject to improve to its full potential of Unreal Engine 4"
+Buildables (Defenses-FOBs)
+Quality infantry Play
+integrated positional VoIP for proximity talking & radio
+Dedicated Servers Max 72 Slot (it will be 100 slot in future) "50v50"
+Tactical Community (Most of the people actually support/listen Squad Leaders) Which is amazing.
+People play their roles. (it's amazing to see Random People come along so good in a game)

Cons of Alpha: (V 4.0)
-Lack of Good Ragdoll and Gore
-No Destructive physics (Can't understand Why as UE4 Supports it)
- No binocular view
-No ieds
-No Vehicles
-Mountains are flat as hell, lack of proper Valley mapping and route for ambush.
-No Tunnel Digging or No Caves (Higher Mountains) Especially for Weapon Cache Mod)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Verdict
Buy now!
Buy on sale
Save your money (for now)

Summary:
The disclaimer here is I had the game but returned for a refund. In it's current state and at the current price I couldn't justify recommending to anyone.

Let me say though - the premise is a great one. Teamwork to the fore as you and your fellow squads work to secure objectives and eliminate the enemy. Some great features like fantastic ingame proximity VOIP really serve to emphasise the teamwork vision the developers have for the game.

Additionally there are no KDR's (Kill Death Ratios), the scoreboard works on a points system so whilst you can see who has contributed the most points on your team it is clear that the focus isn't on the lone wolf soldier just gunning for the best KDR. Here is where the game first comes unstuck, you have no idea who actually killed you - is it the enemy from 300m away or is the the guy team killing on your own team.

And that is a nice summary of where the game is currently at. The idea and vision are great, execution is badly lacking. Given the game is Early Access then I have some tolerance for bugs, but this game desperately needs some quality of life features, even at the expense of a little realism (and let's face it a medic reviving someone who is dead and they go straight back into battle is hardly realistic anyway). Currently at the moment hacking seems to be a real issue as well, which to their credit, the devs acknowledge, but the announced partnership with easy anti-cheat doesn't fill me with confidence.

Throw in the almost AAA price tag for a EA niche game and there is just too much going against this to recommend at the moment. Unless you are an absolute die hard fan, I recommend sitting on the fence and see how this one develops over time.

The Good:
The idea and vision to emphasise teamwork over the individual
Innovative gameplay
Inbuilt VOIP works great

The Bad:
Some real quality of life improvements are needed to enahance gameplay, even at the expense of some realism
Bugs (to be expected with EA but you will need some patience)
Major content still coming (i.e. vehicles)

The Ugly:
Hackers can be a problem on servers
Griefers are a major issue if no active admin
Game currently does not warrant AAA price tag

Overall Score:
5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Squad is the game I've been waiting for for a very long time.  Since before I knew it existed.

I like games like Hostile Intent, Insurgency, Arma, etc. I enjoy more casual games like the Battlefield series, but let's be honest, I prefer games that are more realistic and punishing.

Squad is like taking the best things of Insurgency, Arma, and the Battefield series, combining them, improving them, and then adding to them.

The maps are large, to say the least. The terrain is excellent, and still being improved.

Weapons are fantastic. Iron sights and limited scopes currently. Very well balanced, and they hit hard. No ammo counter or magically refilling magazines.

When you get critically hit you start bleeding out and need to bandage, or find a medic. Medics can pick you up from being downed, but it takes time, and after being downed twice, you won't be picked up again, you have to respawn. Just one of many game mechanics that I feel really balances things out. You can't be revived 37 times in a row by a medic sitting behind the wall reviving you over and over.

9 man squads are well balanced. You can't make a new squad to get the one sniper class or rpg. As more people join your squad, the rest of the classes are unlocked, to make sure every squad is balanced.

You can communicate to your own squad anywhere on the map, and in direct chat you can communicate with other friendlies from other squads. It's very well done. The in game voice quality is the best of any game I've ever played.

Squad leaders can communicate with other squad leaders via a 3rd voice chat option to coordinate attacks/defense/assistance.

Squad leaders, when near 1 friendly player, can drop a rally point, where their own squad members can spawn. It only has 9 spawn points, and you can only place 1 every 2 minutes. If an enemy gets near it it goes away.

Squad leaders can also build FOBs, where any player on your team can spawn, and there is no limit to spawns. You spawn faster at fobs than rally's. Your squad leader can design defensive structures to secure your fob, and the other players have to get out their shovels and build what the squad leader designed.

FOB building is very well done, in that it takes time, resources, and teamwork to build, and they can only be build a certain distance apart, so you don't end up with teams having 20 spawn points all over the map. On a good team you generally will see maybe 2 FOBs, possibly 3. Again every aspect of the game seems very well balanced, and it's still in its infancy.

This game is amazing as it is, and it doesn't even have land or air vehicles yet. It's constantly being updated and worked on. It's only getting better.

You haven't played a great large scale realistic FPS until you've tried Squad.
voteText: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR, buy Squad if you

- Like slow paced gameplay compared to something like Battlefield, but faced paced gameplay compared to Arma
- Enjoy really working in a team. Like, REALLY. You MUST work well with your team if you want to win
- Enjoy playing a variety of distinct roles
- Like longer shooter match lengths
- Enjoy a combination of strategy and action
- If you're a social gamer (not as necessary, you can get by without being massively talkative, but a mic is still an absolute must)

Avoid it if you

- Don't have a mic (seriously, just get one, they're cheap as chips)
- Want a large variety of game modes
- Want shoot-em-up action all the time
- Have little patience
- Don't like taking directions/advice from other players
- Want to lone-wolf/do your own thing
- Have an AMD CPU. There are some serious Unreal Engine issues plaguing AMD users right now. Probably avoid Squad until they iron them out.

Before I dive into my actual review, I want to mention that I've played over 500 hours of Arma 3, and that that's where the majority of my shooter experience comes from. I've also played a decent chunk of Project Reality, the BF2 mod that Squad is based on. In my opinion, Squad is a far superior game to Arma 3, and even though they both scratch different itches and are very different games, Squad is probably going to be my go to tactical/'realistic' shooter for at least the next 2 years.

Squad isn't the first game to do what it's doing. If you've played Project Reality (and if you haven't, I really recommend it before buying Squad, it's free) you've basically played Squad with vehicles and dated graphics. However, it does do what it sets out to do extremely well.

A lot of reviewers have described Squad as being 'slow-paced' and while there's some truth to that, I would put it a different way. Squad has a fair bit of down time where you're just walking between objectives, chatting and dropping banter with your squadmates. When you're actually engaged in a firefight, there's nothing slow paced about Squad at all. You're constantly forced to make micro decisions that could lead to your entire squad being wiped out if you screw up, especially if you're playing a vital role such as medic or squad leader.

Ultimately what Squad comes down to is the effectiveness of squad leaders and how well they can utilise their squad members' abilities. A single fantastic squad can turn the tide of a seemingly hopeless round, and this happens quite often. This means that even the currently winning team's squad leaders have to be really switched on and constantly on the lookout for game making plays from other squads. Understanding how the maps flow is pretty key to this. I won't talk about how to squad lead specifically, but a great squad leader can literally win the game for you. It doesn't matter if you've got 50 amazing marksmen on your team if there's no one to coordinate them into killing as many of the baddies as possible.

The gunplay is extremely satisfying and has a lot of really impressive visual and audio feedback. Full auto, or even burst fire is only really viable on the AK model weapons. The M16 and M4 simply recoil too much to be effective on full auto at anything over about 20 metres. The US weapons do come with pretty great optics though, which means that the US team will usually try to engage at longer ranges, while Insurgents will attempt to sneak up closer. This lends a pretty interesting assymetric balance to firefights.

The audio in this game is almost on par with something like DICE's Battefield 4 or Battlefront. It's seriously impressive and actually pretty important to your survivability. Tracing where gunshots came from, or listening to an enemy fireteam run through the field you're lying in informs all those micro decisions you're constantly making. The visuals are pretty much what you'd expect too, with some nice lighting effects and some really atmospheric and immersive vistas on some of the maps. Could probably use a bit more polish, but nothing to complain about really.

I could talk loads more about this game, but if any of what I said sounds interesting to you, go try out Project Reality. If you like that, get Squad. They're different, especially since Squad doesn't have vehicles yet, but they scratch the same itch. Some of the most tense and satisfying gaming moments I've had have been in Squad.

I'll update this review as the game gets patched.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking for a game that focuses on teamwork rather than individual skill and takes a more fun approach towards realism *meaning it has the better aspects of realism but gameplay will always outweigh it* then this is the game for you.  Although this game is currently in the early stages of the development cycle it definitely delivers solid gameplay mechanics and visuals. The flow of the game is great. It's not perfect but with every single update it gets better and better - a vital sign of the developers listening to community feedback and improving on their previous releases.

One of my favourite aspects of SQUAD is that this game is intense, and I truly mean intense. Whether you're in a small server with 5 players on each team or in the huge cluster of chaos that is a 50v50 player warzone.. you're going to experience exactly what the developers are working to achieve - capturing combat realism through communication and team play (and this is currently with just infantry based combat.. vehicles (transports, logistics, APCs / IFVs, helos...) improvement / additions to gameplay mechanics are going to multiply this intensity). Ever watch one those deployment videos from Iraq, Afghanistan or Eastern Ukraine? One second you're strolling to an objective and the next SHTF and you're engaged in a 15 minute long firefight with the enemy players.

All in all..SQUAD is by FAR one of the best shooters I've played and is a prime example of a game made by developers that get engaged in playing side by side with their community. If you're looking to experience a game that will deliver both as a solid title AND be a stellar example of an ongoing game in development.. say no more.

This game certainly has a long way to go and there are regular news updates and posts on hotfixes / noted issues but with a little bit of time and the great supportive community it will be way more than any Project Reality vet could have imagined and will definitely be the go to title for players that enjoy gaming in tight knit squads, large maps, immersive engagements and atmospheric environments.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever since the Xbox 360 shipped with a headset packaged as standard, online games have yearned to create the kind of cooperative multiplayer seen only in advertisements and well-rehearsed E3 demos.

Outside of these scripted environments very few games have put emphasis on voice chat. Sure, we’ve had games like those in the SOCOM series and MAG which have tried to varying degrees of success but the simple truth is that outside a certain genre of game, voice chat just isn’t used. Hell, even in the most competitive games out there today it’s rare to find people using voice chat.

Squad, on the other hand, is one of the few games which seems to be doing voice chat right. Boot up Squad today and within a few minutes you’ll have a voice telling you where to go and what to do. If taking orders isn’t your thing you can be that voice telling others where to go and what to do. It’s actually very close to what MAG was trying to do, except it’s on a platform where people actually have microphones. You also probably won’t have to worry about servers shutting off making the game unplayable. Even though it’s still in an alpha state, Squad has a thriving active community of players. If anything about MAG sounded appealing to you, Squad is the game that actually delivers on those ideas.

The developers behind Squad started out making a relatively popular mod for Battlefield 2 called Project Reality. Project reality built upon Battlefield 2 adding new levels of realism and a vastly increased scope. It looked better, it played better, its custom-made maps spanned dozens of kilometers. It’s one of the best fan mods out there today. It seems that all of this experience has translated perfectly into Squad with its vast maps and team-focused gameplay.

Squad is unique in that in can take minutes to get to anything resembling action but good leadership will ensure you’re never out of the fray for too long. It’s as if someone took an objective-based first person shooter like Battlefield and added the massive scale and openness of DayZ. As a result Squad it definitely a game you’ll enjoy more if you’re playing with a group of people you know. That’s not to say you can’t have fun alone but just like in other games where communication plays a key role – like Trouble in Terrorist Town – you’re going to have more fun after you and the people you’re playing with have built up a rapport.

It’s hard to be too critical of Squad because it’s still in active development but what I can say is that the gameplay feels extremely solid. Most of the things that need to be improved before the commercial release are related to the UI and tutorials because as a new player it can be very difficult to know what you should do which becomes a very intimidating problem, especially when other people are relying on you to perform your role.

Unlike most early access games, Squad actually offers a fun playable experience. If you’re on the fence about spending the money, maybe wait until the official release but if you’re excited to play right now, it’s well worth the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, this game is the real deal. I've been looking for a game like this for a long time. Ever since seeing Dyslexci's Arma 3 videos on the Shack Tac Youtube channel, I've been looking to get more into Milsim games. I'm just not the kinda guy to join a clan though, and without one, Arma 3 is not at all like those amazing videos you see online.

Squad though... This is it. You don't need a clan with mandatory attendence, you don't need to spend 10 hours creating a mission, you don't even need friends. Join a server, pick a squad, you're in. Suddenly, you're in a massive battlefield with multiple squads working together, with people actually talking to each other. Your squad leader will guide you, tell you what the squad is currently up to. Maybe defending a FOB (player-created secondary objective), maybe coordinating with another 9-person squad to flank an enemy position atop a fortified hill... For the first time, I actuallty felt like I was in a Dyslexci video.

After a round, you kind of feel like you got to know your squad a little. Leaders have different styles, making games very different. You've got your roleplay-heavy medic screaming at you to hang on, that he's coming for you, as frags go off left and right. You've got the guy yelling about the glory of Chechnya. I feel a little  sad to see a good squad break up after a game.

Overall, this game looks incredibly promising. Solid Milsim action that is very easy to get into yet seems incredibly hard to master.

Disclaimer, you need a mic to play this game. Don't even think about it otherwise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, where should I begin?  Squad is something special.  It sores very high while it’s flying, and perhaps falters ever so slightly when it’s not, mostly due to other people.  The development team has laid out a yellow brick road that seems to be on track.  Make no mistake, if you have hungered for something real, something tactical and representative of intense visceral infantry (and perhaps in the future, vehicular) combat, this is that game.

The genius of squad lays in what it creates.  Emergent, medium scale infantry combat based around team play.  Switching weapons takes a bit of time, as does preparing a grenade or smoke grenade to throw.  Moving is not very quick.  These are all good things, because it creates an environment where you need to think before you act.  It really isn't that hard to understand what this game is about.  Think of an instance that countless people have shared and that seems to be the staple of amazing moments in Squad.  You and your 8 person squad is moving to an objective on a map that represents a few square miles (they are big map).  You have a general idea of where you’ll meet the enemy, but there are no guarantees. It seems slow.  You all decide to stop and drop a rally point.  You here a hiss of bullet cross your plane past you nearby.  There's no 'snap' so you know it’s not exactly on you, but it’s nearby.  Maybe you hear a few more hissing bullets scream by, and then a snap.  You hit B" to engage squad comm's and begin to tell your squad you think you’re being shot at.  An explosion of gun fire erupts

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs
3 tablespoons sugar
3 tablespoons melted butter
40 ounces softened cream cheese
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons flour
1 tablespoon vanilla
1 cup sour cream
4 eggs

Directions:
For The base:.
If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.
Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.
Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.
For the batter:.
Make sure everything is at room temperature.
Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.
Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.
Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.
Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.
Release the sides of the springform.
Eat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the game I've always dreamt of.
You are either a Squad Leader, or Medic or any kind of troop in one of the teams, forming an army. You follow the orders of the SLs and must constantly keep an eye open to enemies and your teammates.
Where is everyone? What is the optimal position to hold? Where is the SL? Are my teammates ok? These are all questions you keep asking yourself throughout the game. Stick to the squad because you DON'T want to get killed. Medics already have plenty to do and you don't want to be that guy who has to walk half the map to find a weakened squad. You are just a troop following orders being constantly fully aware of the surroundings. That's it.
I purchased this game in January 2016 when it still was and is in Alpha. Yet this game has so much potential, for reasons I will explain.
The concept
You follow your role and stick to it. You always follow the orders. This could be holding a base, helping other teams, etc. The goal is to, I think, to conquer as much of the map as possible.
The game itself
The game itself is relatively demanding on hardware for the graphics it carries, but it should be acceptable. Don't expect anything too fancy (yet). I haven't played many games but the level of realism in the maps is a bit better than Far Cry. The player interactions are proper.
Communication is something this game has a great focus on, having implemented somewhat realistic means of voice chat. You can call teammates and squad leaders and troops in a 20 m radius, which is pretty neat. Also good chat implementation.
I don't know what's up with the servers but they're always full so you'll have to choose a server far away with high ping. The people are very kind and don't yell at you, which is what you also shouldn't do. Given the complexity of the game and the amount of awareness needed to play it, you should understand that you aren't the center of attention even if you are the top fragger who just got killed. You deal with it as a group where the ambiance is a factor as well. This is probably why I love the game the most.
Conclusion
The game has extremely lots of potential. If you have the money and find it very interesting, buy it. You will find yourself playing it for many hours. Otherwise just wait until it's out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played the various alpha builds of SQUAD for many hours before it was on steam and now having played the latest build on steam I must say its awesome to see how much this game has grown. Do you like realistic shooters? SQUAD may be for you.

The maps are large and and the terrain is very varied, so this is not a run and gun game. A microphone I would truly recommend if you want to experience the game fully. Coordinating with a squad is fun as hell and makes you feel like you're part of an outfit. Being the squad leader is also a important position, because you need those forward operating bases in order to help your team spawns. Excellent FOBs can certainly win a game for you, so its not all about your aim.

The game has squad voice chat, and even local directional voice chat, so if there's a teammate calling for help or pointing out a target, he could just use the local voice chat to warn nearby teammates. Its an awesome feature.

I have complete faith in the developers to pull this off. They've added so much in the alpha builds and I can't wait to see the future vehicles and features.

Performance wise: I have a GTX 770, and a i7 3770K and the game runs at a mixture of high/epic settings around 50 FPS at 1080p for me. The game uses Unreal Engine 4.

If there's any Project Reality (BF2 mod) players reading this, SQUAD is definitely most similar to PR in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tired of COD and Battlefield?  Arma 3 still getting crap framerates?  Want realistic warfare simulation?  This is the game for you.  My group of friends and I have been searching (longing) for an experience we first had in a mod, called Red Orchestra.  Originally a mod for Unreal 2003 engine.  RO, the mod created an experience unlike any other.  You'd fight for hours upon hours.  Each life feeling like it could be your last as your reinforcements drained away.  It actually felt like the people you fought with were your Band of Brothers.  So much so, that till this day, over 10 years later, we still are that Band of Brothers.

The devs of RO took the game into retail, slightly increasing it's small dedicated community.  The retail version, while still good, was not the equal of the mod.  Eventually after years of promise, and diversions to other games, the devs returned with RO 2.  With it's return, the devs forgot and neglected the hard-core fan base.  They ignored suggestions during alpha and beta testing.  All in hopes of attracting more from the COD and BF crowd.  In the end they pleased no one.  They sold their souls for the almighty dollar and got nothing in return.

Finally Squad has come.   Squad incorporates the feeling of small unit tactics (squad of up to 9 playes), into a larger battlefield (servers range from 30 players on up to 72).   You feel like you are taking part in a battle.  Maybe you have a few minutes of quiet while marching to the objective.  Then suddenly all hell breaks loose and someone screams who's doing the SHOOTING!" .  Bullets whiz by your head.  You drop to the ground
date: frantically trying to figure where the gunfire is coming from.  Your squad mates are dropping like flies around you.  You grab your med pack and try to put some of your buddies back into the fight.  Then all goes black and you start screaming MEDIC!\n\nIf you are looking for something more than running around a small map and twitch shooting the first guy you see

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SQUAD is a large scale, conventional warfare, team-based tactical shooter that borders on being a military simulator without actually crossing that line; it's a game first and foremost. I've been playing the game since its early Closed Alpha up until release, and when I say it's one of the best shooters I've ever played, I mean that sincerely. It finds this level of realism that feels incredibly authentic, even up against other notable titles in its genre.

Communication is paramount for success. A microphone is strongly recommended. In-game comms shapes the experience in a way that is unmatched by any other shooter I have played, and is what helps to deliver that authentic experience. Join a squad, pick a role, listen to your squad leader, work as a team, and you'll come out on top. If not, prepare to be crushed by coordinated, cohesive strikes from the opposition.

[Edit]: Will update the review as time goes on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the most immersive military FPS I have played since the original Operation Flashpoint.

I cannot recommend this game enough for anyone that has the slightest interest in realistic shooters but wants to actually HAVE FUN at the same time.

PROS:

- Balance of realism and arcade almost as good as it was in Red Orchestra (the original)
- As intense as a fight in EVE Online when with good players against good players
- The sound is amazing. Sound is actually the best way of locating enemy forces
- Weapon modules are awesome
- 50 vs 50! (although most servers are 50, 60 or 72 players atm)

CONS:

- Requires people to lead, communicate and be mature to be fun. With how new the game is on Steam, it will take a while.
- No Friends system yet. This game will be more fun if you are able to hook up with the cool players you met online and join servers together
- Currently no indication of wether or not your team is doing well. This is damaging the immersion a bit
- Non-US forces are lacking in optics a bit too heavily. It's good that optics are not ubiquitous though, as it forces more team play

TIP:

Talk! Even if you have a squad leader that does not talk, talk to him and encourage him. You will waste your time in a non-responsive squad for an hour+ easily if you put up with silence.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My squad was pushing up to take the farm compound. The squad leader orders me to stay back and support them with my scoped sniper rifle. While I am watching the roofs I hear a shot behind me. I immediately drop to prone and check the map. Nothing is showing up where I am, and that can only mean enemies. Thankfully I had positioned myself in a waist high poppy field so there is no way they can see me. The thing is though I can see them through the stalks of the flowers running by me. They also must have shot at someone else because they have no clue I am there. What the enemy squad thought was a great flanking route to take on my squad has now turned into their worst nightmare. As they approached me  I radio in my position to the squad leader and let him know of the situation. He cannot spare anyone to come back and aid me, so now it is up to me to keep them occupied. They run past and with their backs to me I get in the kneeled position and shoot two of them dead. I get prone and slink off to their right while they toss grenades into the field. I take no damage. They knew the shots were close but they do not know where I went. Their medic tries to go and revive one of the soldiers and I shoot him dead. They were a smaller squad of seven so I had just killed their only medic. Now I have effectively stalled their attack because there are only four of them left with no way to revive. They toss another grenade and miss again. I'm wishing now that I could hear their radio chatter because I am sure they freaking out trying to locate me. I slowly snaked up to the wall of the field and looked on the other side. I see two more and I take them out, but I get hit in the process and I go down. Moments later the last two are killed as my squad had taken the compound and had returned to aid me. Our medic revives me and I recieve verbal praise from my squad as we go back to occupy the control point.

10/10 Would save the day again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine a universe where games could procreate much like we do.  Now imagine Battlefield 4 and ARMA III had a baby.  SQUAD would be the result of such a joining and what we have in EARLY ACCESS could be considered the infant years of what will eventually grow up to become a game that sits somewhere in the middle between an arcade FPS and a military simulation.

If that sounds good to you like it did me I suggest you pick up this diamond in the rough.  While it still has a few jagged edges such as performance issues and missing features they eventually plan to add (Vehicles as an example) the game still holds up for an EARLY ACCESS release and is quite enjoyable if you go into it with the right mindset.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPurchased at the start of the Kickstart program back in may and the game has exeeded my expectations (which were very high). This game is for people that like real time tactical gameplay that is all about teamwork (squad) rather than your average FPS run and gun game, in order to win in this game you have to have a plan and also be able to exicute that plan with your team and the squads within that team.  The deployables and base biulding is a amazing part of the game. This is a one of a kind game and should not be thought of as a ARMA like game because it is very different from ARMA in many ways. I will update this review as i get further into the game and as updates are released. The game runs great for me but some servers are a bit laggy, as long as you select a good server to join and adjust the settings to what your PC can run without problems, there are some times while in brush or high amounts of deployables where you will have a FPS drop but i have been able to play without lag (on the correct servers). I highly reccomend buying this game if you want the expiereince of real war and fire fights, there is not a game that comes close to Squad as far as realism. BUY IT. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSquad is hands down the best computer game I have ever played.  I first started with Halo, BF2/3, COD, MW1-3, etc.....even ventured into the world of Uncharted 1-3 and thoroughly enjoyed it that is until that one fateful day last summer when I was watching a Project Reality livestream and heard the players discussing a new tactical FPS called Squad. I can honestly say that I enjoy the game so much that not only do I play it every day of the week, but I actually lose sleep daily to play this game, because I set an alarm to wake me up three hours before work just to play - that's how addictive this game is!!  And for someone like me with no PC FPS gaming experience to come in literally blind and pick up the strategies and game play in a matter of a few hours is testimony enough for any person that has a competitive FPS bone in their body.  My wife constantly rolls her eyes every time she sees me playing this game, but I just snicker knowing that I am continuing to grow and learn the meta inside the game while she sits at her PC staring at her social media black hole. reviewText:
Early Access Review

The developers of SQUAD set out with many goals in mind. Not only did they want to bring to life a new iteration of a game we all played and loved (Project Reality), they wanted to do it their way, which meant trying to achieve a relatively transparent dev. process, and do away with the trust issues we all have from early access games. Squad is in an Alpha stage of development that would pass for a complete game by the standards other EA games have set in the last few years. On top of these things theyre also on the way to achieving the rush that only people who truly played Project Reality could get, when you value youre game life enough to actually have your heart skip a beat, and you get to see how you really react under the stress of fire. Something i find very tough to explain, but you will know once you play SQUAD.

The GOOD:
-High quality audio, textures, models, and effects. seriously you can just sit and watch a  firefight and still get a rush
-Accurate models and factions with proper equipment. A must for vets and military nerds alike!
-In-game VOIP allows a level of communication not seen in other FPS's. you can talk to people near you with positional audio, or you can talk to another Squad Leader across the map.
-Speaking of maps. even without pushing the engine to its limits the maps are HUGE compared to alot of FPS's. im not talking ARMA scale, but 4kmx4km will give you plenty of flanking room.
-Very few gamey elements. A big part of the idea of SQUAD is that you should be able to get easily immersed. Your enemies dont pop up as red dots anywhere, the only way you can know where the enemy is is by communicating with other team-mates, or walk towards the gunfire.
-Buildable FOBS! this is one of the things brought over from PR, and with the new engine it is just awesome! You can make your own objectives within a game. Stuck in a stalemate, or just dont like the flag you have to attack? Build a giant fortress at the top of the hill and make the enemy come to you!
-Medic System. If you get wounded, you dont just wait 3 seconds and spawn on your squad leader. in SQUAD you rely on a medic to heal you even if youve been dropped, he first has to bandage your wounds, then heal you, then you can get back in the fight. the system is still being worked on all the time but it is already a nice mechanic, and the long spawn or walk times to get back to your squad are a good incentive to keep the squad together and keep your medic safe!

The BAD:
-Game pretty much requires a microphone to get the most out of it, you can get pretty cheap mics, but some people cant be screaming at insurgents all night while their baby/family sleeps. an unfortunate problem.
-Performance issues. Incase youve forgot at this point, this game is still in ALPHA, theres gonna be problems. the devs work constantly to resolve these problems. dont freak out because you cant play, go to the forums and report it and it will be fixed sooner :).
-Bugs. again from the above point, ALPHA. there are still some bugs to flesh out, none of the major bugs are game breaking so it shouldnt be a point against buying the game, just report them when you find them!

Conclusion:
If you're looking for more out of your FPS experience, if you get frustrated by the stupidity you see in other games, if you just need to blow something up, join us in SQUAD. It's like if ARMA and Insurgency got freaky, and then their baby got raised by Project Reality. What more could you want?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're searching for a shooter that is more serious, but not too serious like Arma, then go for Squad. It's one of the best milsim FPS games out there in my opinion. They are constantly working on the game, and are really there for the players. They are working very hard on their game and really take pride in it. Squad has great potential, and it will be a great game when it's finished (whenever that may be)

However, there are, as you probably already figured, also a lot of cons. I could make a whole list of them, but I won't, since I really like the game, and the developers. There are a couple of things that have to be mentioned before you buy though;

- Know that you're buying an Early Access game, this game, as you know, is far, and I mean really, really far from finished. After all this time its been open for the public you'd say it has quite a lot of content, and they would've managed to fix a lot of bugs, but that is not the case. There is not a huge amount of content, and there is also quite an amount of bugs (nothing gamebreaking though).
- There are no vehicles yet. They just released an update which adds the base of the vehicle system, which is enterable stationary machine guns. This is a huge leap forward, and is great to see. The system they want to be using for the vehicles is just not finished yet. (They've done tests on public servers with vehicles, and that lead to huge problems, both server-sided, and client-sided.
- The optimisation for this game is terrible. The game is so badly optimised, that when you're in a poppy field, you will get a huge fps drop in most cases. Of course this differs from the computer you're using, but it's most likely that even though you have a big fancy gaming pc, you will still get fps drops. I personally think that they should focus on making the game run better, before adding more content (like vehicles). This is the main reason why I haven't been playing Squad that much lately.

Now of course I get viewed upon as a very negative person, who only sees the negative points about things. But please don't think that way. I love this game, it is, as I said, one of the best milsim shooters out there. I definitely recommend it to anyone who likes these kinds of games. I always say it is a fair mix of Arma and Battlefield, where there is huge battlefields and fights, but with a fair amount of realism in it. This is great if you ask me. Also, the community of this game is great (at least, the people I came across). There's so many people who are nice, and actually communicate with other squad leaders and of course their own squads, that is a great thing to see, as you don't see that in most games, I also came across a lot of people who are hilarious as hell, saying all kinds of things in their mics. And the last thing I want to say is about the developers, they are great. Almost every month they release a huge update with both new content, and fixes. They are busy with their game day in day out, and that is great. Also they carefully respond to questions on their forums and on reddit, which is also a great thing.

So should you get this game? Yes, if you like these kinds of games, and are willing to live with the things I listed, then just buy it. The price might seem a bit much, but just see it as an investment, you will have an even more amazing game when its finished. If you are still hesitating to buy it, then just follow Squad for a while, the updates will pop up in your Activity page on Steam. That way you can see what happens with the game, and what they are up to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you enjoyed Battlefield 2 and Project Reality and want a middle ground between ArmA and some of the newer more casual game FPS you're looking at the right game.

Teamwork within the squad and between the squads on a team is essential. Communication is also vital. You cannot mindlessly twitch this game as it requires more thought and patience. Huge maps. Amazing sounds.

The game isn't finished and has its rough spots and I'll update this review as it reaches completion (vehicles, more basebuilding, game modes, 100 player servers and polish) The team seems to be commited to a vision and will not yield to those clammoring for a more accesible and casual experience which are all good things.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a great community. It offers the perfect level of realism, it's not boring and too in depth like Arma (in my opinion) but has the perfect amount of tactical play along with actual action.

I'm blown away by how much people actually use team work here. I'd say 4/5 squads I'll join are actually communicating and working together. It really shines when there is communication going on but is frustrating and no fun if your without a good squad but luckily it's very easy to find a good group of players. I actually bought a mic specifically for Squad.

The performance isn't the best yet I get about 50fps on average on my 970 but it's obviously still in Alpha and they plan on adding vehicles this month too.

This game is very promising and has a great community surrounding it. I'd highly reccomend it if you need something fresh because your sick of AAA fps meat grinders.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played in a squad for the US Army and the leader was Donald J. Trump. Americans got destroyed.
10/10 This game can tell the future.

---------------------------------------------------------------
Jokes aside, ONLY GET THIS GAME IF YOU ARE WILLING TO GET ALL TACTICAL

First up, this game is going to force you to play together. The maps are huge, and you will need to stick together with your squad. Set up rally points, build FOBs, anyrhing that you can fall back on when you go down. No one wants to walk kilometers from their main base to get to the frontlines. Long respawn timers increase based on how many teammates you've killed, how fast you gave up without waiting for a medic, and how fast you've died after respawning. You want to make sure you are with a nearby medic, so as I just said, stay close.

Next, this game is going to be tough and infuriating. Death will come from places you will never expect, and you are definitely going to bleed out and get knocked out even as you think you are safe under those bushes. Adjust your mentality as you get into this game, realise that kills don't mean ♥♥♥♥, that deaths and respawn waste your team's tickets, and adjust your playstyle. Listen to your leader, play the objectives and focus on supporting your squadmates.

This game is a mix between Insurgency and ArmA, with the intensity of Insurgency's close quarter environments and the scale of ArmA's map. Find Insurgency too fast-paced? Find ArmA too slow and buggy? This game is just perfect for you.

Keep your head down soldier, this is no Call of Duty.
